content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays three separate pieces of tissue against a white background. These tissues are ovoid to irregular in shape and stain intensely basophilic (purple), which is characteristic of lymphoid tissue. I suspect these are three lymph nodes. The largest lymph node on the left has an irregular contour and seems to be almost completely replaced by the dense cellular infiltrate, raising suspicion for pathology, either metastasis or a lymphoma. The other two nodes also appear densely cellular.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am examining the first and largest lymph node from the top-left. When assessing lymph nodes for metastasis, it is crucial to examine the entire node, including the subcapsular sinus, the cortex, the medulla, and the capsule itself. The zoom is directed towards the periphery of the lymphoid tissue, where it abuts the surrounding pericapsular fat. This is a critical area to evaluate for potential tumor deposits, capsular invasion, and extracapsular extension, which are important for staging. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am examining the second (middle) lymph node from the left. I've zoomed into the periphery of the lymphoid tissue, at the interface with the surrounding pericapsular adipose tissue. This is a critical area to assess for several reasons: 1) To check the subcapsular sinus, which is the first place metastatic cells often deposit. 2) To evaluate the integrity of the lymph node capsule and look for any signs of extranodal extension (tumor cells breaching the capsule and invading the surrounding fat), which is a significant prognostic factor. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. This is the second lymph node from the left. I am zooming into the periphery of this node, specifically at the interface between the dense cellular component and the surrounding fatty tissue. This is a critical area to examine for two main reasons: 1) To identify the lymph node capsule and determine if it is intact. 2) To assess for extranodal extension (ENE), which is the invasion of tumor cells through the capsule into the surrounding fat. ENE is a very important prognostic factor. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area of the first lymph node (top left) because at low power, the normal, dark, uniform architecture of the lymphoid tissue appears disrupted. There are paler, more eosinophilic (pink) and irregular areas that contrast with the surrounding lymphocytes. This pattern is highly suspicious for metastatic carcinoma, which often replaces the normal lymphoid parenchyma with nests or glands of tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a dense, monotonous sheet of small, round, dark-staining cells with scant cytoplasm, consistent with small lymphocytes. These cells efface the normal lymph node architecture. To the left of the field, there is mature adipose tissue (pericapsular fat) and some fibrous connective tissue. In this specific field, I do not see any definite nests, glands, or clusters of atypical epithelial cells that would indicate metastatic adenocarcinoma. The appearance is more in keeping with a lymphoproliferative process, such as chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma (CLL/SLL), which can be an incidental finding. However, a thorough search of the entire node is necessary to definitively rule out metastatic carcinoma.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I can see a sheet of dense, dark-staining small lymphocytes, characteristic of a lymph node. This lymphoid tissue is sharply demarcated from the adjacent mature adipose tissue (fat) at the bottom of the image. The fibrous capsule of the lymph node appears intact. I do not see any atypical cells, glandular structures, or nests of tumor cells that would be indicative of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific area is that it is a benign/reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see a sheet of densely packed, dark purple (basophilic) cells on the left, which are characteristic of metastatic carcinoma. On the right, I see mature adipose tissue (fat cells). The key finding is that the tumor cells are directly abutting and infiltrating into the adipose tissue without a clear, intervening fibrous lymph node capsule. This finding is diagnostic of extranodal extension (ENE). Therefore, my impression is that this is a lymph node positive for metastatic carcinoma with associated ENE. The small black deposits are likely surgical ink.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in area, I see the parenchyma of a lymph node, characterized by a dense population of small, round lymphocytes. This lymphoid tissue is extensively infiltrated by irregular, back-to-back and cribriform glands composed of atypical epithelial cells. These tumor cells are larger than the lymphocytes, with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm and enlarged, hyperchromatic, and pleomorphic nuclei. The features are characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma.
